post.content:
3️⃣0️⃣ Here's the 30th post highlighting key new features of the upcoming v258 release of systemd. #systemd258

systemd's service sandboxing logic builds heavily on Linux mount namespacing, as well as other types of process namespacing. It primarily uses to this to take away access to certain subhierarchies (i.e. marking them read-only, unmounting them or overmounting them with something else), but it also allows to rearrange things (i.e. bind mount one dir onto another, obstructing access to it).

fields.name: Web
fields.value: http://0pointer.de/blog/

replies.content:
This is all very efficient to secure services, but it's also a bit opaque: since it's the daemon you sandbox, and your admin tools are outside of that sandbox it's sometimes hard to analyze how the daemon sees things.

No more. With v258 there's a new verb "unit-shell" in systemd-analyze. You specify a service name, and it opens you a shell inside that specified services' sandbox (which must be running for this). You can look around and check if everything is like you expected it to be.

fields.name: Web
fields.value: http://0pointer.de/blog/

lennart_followups.content:
In a way this is somewhat equivalent to `nsenter -a -p $(systemctl show -P MainPID $UNIT)`, but this new tool is a bit more careful as well as nicely integrated in our tool set. It's lovely, and I have been using this myself quite a few times already since we merged it a few days ago.

What's best about all this is that this new addition has been contributed by @zihco as part of of the Outreachy program!

fields.name: Web
fields.value: http://0pointer.de/blog/

all_descendants.content:
@pid_eins does this only work for running services or does it also with non-running ones to e.g. debug why MainPID isn't starting as expected?

@zihco

all_descendants.content: @eliasp this verb only works for running services. A follow up verb will be added for non running services.

@zihco from a UX perspective it would be cool to have it in a single verb, as user don't need to learn and remember two verbs.

What ist the behavior if my main service is crash looping and by chance I just land in the running service unit? Will the shell go away together with my service?
@eliasp

account.note: Programming Operationsguy, Kubernetes, Golang, firefighter, cycler and father

all_descendants.content: @ada_magicat , yes, having both as one verb is a better UX, but implementing the later is a bit trickier and may need the service state engine to be extended with a new state
@zihco @eliasp I'm also curious as to the technical limitations and why it would be a different verb.
